pros: Good benefits and PTO policies. Flexible management. Overall great working environment, with understanding supervisors.
cons: Poor compensation methods. This varies by unit, but the largest issue is the discrepancies in staff compensation, especially with management. An employee in "Department A" can make 1/2 of what an employee in "Department B" is compensated for doing the same job, regardless of experience, simply because the departments have different views on how a job description fits within a state title and pay grid. Some departments have many administrative employees focusing on specific tasks, and others have one person who does it all but isn't compensated for having those skillsets. Because of this situation, there is no clear path for administrative employees to advance, and compensation gaps are large. HR rubber stamps these position requests when they truly need a full evaluation and re-structuring of departmental and administrative unit staffing positions. Other universities have recently gone through this process.

cons: The University of Arkansas has a very large number of employees and students. They are growing in enrollment and retention rates, yet they are not offsetting this influx. I had issues getting into the system to log hours when I first began working as a TA. I know they had just transitioned into a new system, and a couple of HR reps for my school were very polite and helpful. However, when I called the general HR offices, the response was along the lines of "We do not know. We are just now learning the system." I kept receiving emails and requests for paperwork and documentation which I had already sent, per their request, the week before the semester began. And the issues continued from there for quite a while. It took more than a month to receive my first paycheck, which was supposed to have been released within the first week or so of classes beginning. The issues have since resolved, and I appreciate the help I received, but this never should have been a problem. On top of this, there is an $1,800 cap per semester for TAs that are paid $12 an hour. I work in an advanced course, in one of the most rigorous programs in the university, and I easily work more than my allowed 10-13 hours. I am not paid for the additional hours I work though, due to the pay cap. I enjoying working with the two instructor's which have led the courses I TA for, but the compensation does not meet the value of the work. Minimum wage also increased in 2021, but the hourly rate for TAs did not. I wish the university as a whole would recognize the importance of TAs and their work, while compensating them a little better.

job_title: Coordinator for Communications in Fayetteville, AR
pros: I'll start off by stating that I grew up in Fayetteville so this town and university are like home to me. With that said, this is a wonderful place to work. Before coming back to Arkansas I was working for Brown University. I was completely unimpressed with that institution. Once you get past the wow factor of working at an "Ivy" there were major flaws with the university. Arkansas is the complete opposite. You are treated very well here. The pay is what you expect from a public institution so if you're fine with that then you'll enjoy it here. Fayetteville is well below the national average for cost of living and is a very safe town with a lot to do. Full-time employees receive a 90% tuition break which allows you to go to school for virtually nothing. You are even allowed to take up to three hours of classes during the day and not required to make that time up. The retirement and health benefits are spectacular here. In my department I can say without a doubt that people are treated with respect which I couldn't say about Brown. The first Friday of every month we have a lunch party and recognize the employee of the month. I cannot say enough about how happy I am here. It truly is a wonderful place to work.
cons: I suppose the dental allowance insurance could be higher. After half a year here that is only complaint. That says something about this place that I literally cannot find a con from working here.

review_title: A great springboard for your career!
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Fayetteville, AR
pros:
Really great people, most of them very accessible (even if you have to schedule a week or two in advance). Excellent opportunities in training and use for specialized equipment. 
Many opportunities to network and make contacts from all over the world! Lots of extra-curricular activities to learn more about different areas in your field, or completely new things.
A growing institution that is handling things very well!
Many ways to pay/get paid for graduate school; private funding, corporate funding, TA positions, local start ups, you name it and go for it (in the science/engineering side of things anyway), you got plenty of ways to obtain funding. 
Hours can be erratic yet flexible, great for me personally, but this is not a steady 9-5 (unless you work hard at making it that), if that'w what you're looking for.
cons:
Depending on your personality, it can be hard to get noticed or get things changed if you personally do not take charge to make it happen. In other words, not very clear direction. Your time here really is what you make it. 
Pay is so-so, especially for students, but I mean, what else do you expect for a university.

job_title: Administrative Specialist II in Fayetteville, AR
pros: good benefits-- long christmas break, holidays off, good health insurance provided by U of A
cons: AWFUL parking for staff with yellow parking passes-- I can't tell you how many parking tickets I've received just because I can't find a parking spot within reasonable distance from my office. Also, pay is embarrassing. I was hired under the title "Administrative Specialist II," but I had the job duties of a Public Relations Specialist-- a $20,000/year difference. I was expected to have a college degree and a wide range of skills, but was paid barely $10/hour ($2/hour more than a janitor). All raise requests were declined-- worked here for almost 3 years and never received a raise. Made it difficult to take my job seriously, and it is honestly shameful that a higher education institution would expect college educated employees to work for $10/hour with no raise prospects-- why go to college if this is the future to expect? Also, parking passes are several hundred dollars a year-- just another way to cut into my already low salary.

pros:
- Benefits, Benefits, Benefits. 
- They benefits (health, dental, vacation, retirement match, etc.) are all great perks of working here.
cons:
- When upper administration turns over, there is always a 2-3 year lag in goals and clarity. 
- There needs to be a better pay increase structure for faculty and staff. Someone from the outside has a better chance of making more in a given position than someone who applies internally. Any internal increase above 10% has to be approved by the chancellor.

pros: In general, I like the students I teach. I have a lot of freedom regarding what I teach. The pay is good. My colleagues are collegial, and interesting, and qualified. The University of Arkansas is a strong university, and it is well respected both nationally and internationally. On a good day, it is a fun, interesting, and pleasant place to work.
cons: My cons are specific to my unit. We need a department chair, not just deans. Management often acts like it is controlling faculty, not collaborating with them. The graduate students need to be held to a higher standard in terms of their behavior. The unit could use a much stronger emphasis on publishing. A promotional mailer was sent out our unit with no mention of the faculty, which was demoralizing.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Fayetteville, AR

-Depending on your department, your experience will vary greatly, from really mean mentors to really successful ones.

pros: Great folks to work with, stable employment, beautiful campus. Really, there are lots of reasons to stay that have kept me here despite the most glaring con.
cons: Pay. OMG, if you're not a sports coach, don't expect to get paid REMOTELY close to a national avg for your field. It's really the only major concern I have. After EIGHT years, I'm still less than 1/2 the national avg for my job. I thought maybe I was just under-performing, but there are many others I've learned that are in the same boat. THIS IS A STATE JOB, though. So I guess you shouldn't expect good pay for a government job.

job_title: Graduate Assistant ­ Equipment in Fayetteville, AR
pros: My boss was great! Always treated with respect and gave me time to work on school. The supervisors allowed its employers to develop their own teaching plans, as well as work together to develop research for their current projects.
cons: Some of the other graduate students or co-workers could be difficult to work with. Some were very stuck in their ways and would not see the other perspective. Other than this minor detail, not much.

pros: I always felt very cared about while at the University of Arkansas. The community is very understanding and appreciative of your work. There is also a lot of room for mobility if you want to move to a new position within.
cons: No real cons for me, but I know others felt that (sometimes) promotions were based more on office politics than merit. There seemed to be a lot of turnover, people coming and going and moving to new positions within a year or two.

pros: The university has some really great benefits.   Most departments are very family oriented and care about work-life balance.  The atmosphere can be quite inspirational when the students are here.  If you love the University and the Razorbacks, I can't think of a better place to work.
cons: It's a bit of a good-ole boy system here.  You can work really hard and be really good at your job but only move up in the system if you know someone in upper management and they like you.

review_title: A lot of friendly people who treat each other like family.
job_title: Technical Analyst in Little Rock, AR
pros: You get a great benefits package. 95% discount on classes, health benefits, retirement and plenty of vacation time. Everyone treats each other like family.
cons: Your salary working at the University of Arkansas is nowhere near the state average for your position.  Sometimes you have to work with people that are incompetent in the areas they should be quite knowledgeable in.

review_title: Good place to get job experience
job_title: Administrative Assistant III in Fayetteville, AR
pros: The department I worked for had some pretty amazing people, doing great things, and I loved the advice and work ethic of my supervisor.
cons:
The main reason I left was my salary. Yes, I loved working here, but unfortunately, it came down to the fact that did not want to live paycheck to paycheck anymore. I had an incredibly busy workload, some very stressful seasons, and I was unhappy because ultimately, the work I put in didn't reflect in the set-salary system. Promotions can literally take a year, unless you are able to be moved to a title that has nothing to do with your job description (and even so, the salary is super low). Working overtime meant nothing because my department didn't pay overtime. Instead, any overtime hours were added to my leave time, which I never had time to take advantage of. 

I'm not saying every department is the same, but low staff salary (especially if you are a non-classified employee, are ridiculously low.  If you're really ready to open your eyes, you should find out how much your supervisors are making (or how much your super hardworking co-workers AREN'T making) by taking advantage of the state salary database. Literally just look  up your state's public college and university salaries and be prepared to cry when you find out you make less than 10% of your supervisors salary. Really. 

- Overworked
- Very underpaid 
- No time to take advantage of vacation benefits
- Upper management keeps rolling out changes without warning the staff, which creates learning curves in the middle of super busy seasons
- Getting promoted is an infuriatingly slow process; especially since wages are already very low
- Yearly "bonus" is a joke
- Yes, you get 90% off tuition, but you can only take a couple of classes a term (if your supervisor approves the time off). 
- Your job title doesn't mean anything. An "administrative assistant" in one department can work 60 hrs a week and barely keep up with the workload and someone with the same title in another department can have a very positive, low-stress experience. It just depends. Consistency would be appreciated.

job_title: Instructor, College Or University in Fayetteville, AR
pros: People there are great!  Loved working in the Math Department.  Students were very receptive for the most part.  Some days were more hectic than most but coming from public schools, it was a nice change.
cons: If you are hired, get it in writing that they are going to re-hire you each semester year after year.  That is what I was told when I started but then was let go at the end of the fall semester due to cut backs.  It is cheaper to have grad students teach the math courses than an experienced educator.

pros: Many job options as a new college student. You're able to work while at school with fair compensation. For example, Resident Assistant, First Year Experience mentor, frot desk assistant to name a few big ones.
cons: If your not into education as a career, it's nothing like to real world but it's a start. Work in the private sector, the banking or consumer goods industry are examples of what the real world is like.

review_title: The experience at the University of Arkansas-Fayetteville, was both very interesting and very educational.
pros: The U. of A. is a very fast growing institution, that has more than doubled it's minority population in the last 13 years.  It is located in one of the areas that has repeatedly been reported as being one of the more favorable areas to live in the country (jobs, educational opportunities, earning power cost of living etc.).  Geographically the area has more available jobs then most places in the country. Economically there appears to be an availability of jobs, most low paying but employment is available. The issue is that there does not appear to be very much concern associated with equal opportunity in the area, or the University. This issue applies to gender, ethic groups, age, etc. etc. etc.
cons:
In the pass 20 years there has never been more than two minorities in any decision making positions in the Finance Department, the Personnel Department, The Police Department, The Administrative Services Department, etc.. etc. etc.. The minority population (students) has increased but combined it does not equal 10% of the total population ( if you do not count "females" as an individual group). 

This attitude of exclusion is very apparent in the faculty structure of the institution. The is a Dean of the Library and Journalism (I think) and recently the Business college.  The present Chancellor has been integrating as fast as the institution will allow him to make changes, but that has been one person every few years.

review_title: The atmosphere is very good and the people are fun to work with. Every one strives to do better.
pros: Very great location. People encourage each other to progress in abilities and understanding, so that we all do better work.
cons: The campus is really large, so getting from one place to another is sometimes extensive. Sometimes communication with supervisor at extension campus is difficult; not quick responses at time when needed for project duties.

pros: People are very pleasant, the quality of life is fantastic - albeit, much slower than in the corporate world.  And, the opportunity to come to work everyday at a world class university, on a beautiful campus, and work with students is truly wonderful.
cons: Expect pay that is pennies on the dollar vs. a corporate role.  And, there is layer upon layer of bureaucracy - so progressing new initiatives can be very, very slow.

review_title: Low pay, but low risk of layoffs
job_title: Project Program Specialist in Fayetteville, AR
pros:
Working in a higher education environment with low levels of stress. 
Low risk of layoffs.
Northwest Arkansas is a great location.
cons:
Low salaries.
Staff are treated like second class citizens compared to faculty.
Top talent gets recruited by private industry.
Difficult to hire and keep good employees due to low pay.
Minimal salary increases do not keep up with the cost of parking and health insurance.
Slow to innovate with new ideas.

review_title: Great benefits, people, and a location that can't be beat.

- Pay can be low as it is regulate by the state

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Fayetteville, AR
pros: Pay is equal to other graduate schools, cost of living is lower in Fayetteville, instrumentation within my department is great, degree is respected
cons: Your graduate experience is very heavily dependent upon your advisor. If your advisor passes away, you may get sloughed off to the next willing person without much say in where you end up.

pros: The UofA is a great place to be employed, people are there to help you succeed in your job. I work with student athletes and it's a great way to be involved in the school and help others.
cons: There are no cons to working at the UofA besides parking. Parking can be a big issue on campus but that is true of all Universities.

review_title: My experience at the university of Arkansas allowed me to develop my professional skills.

cons: Depending on where you work, there may be many instances in which communication between departments is less than optimal. Overall though, this is a great place to work.

pros: I had a great experience at the geology department, University of Arkansas, Fayetteville. I was impressed with the city and the friendliness of the people, students, and the professors.  The professors’ willingness to help the students was their best attribute.  They care about their student's’ success and were more than willing to spend extra time to achieve that.
cons: There is none that I can think of currently. Everything worked out just fine for me personally. There are no cons as far as I am concerned.

job_title: Administrative Support Supervisor in Fayetteville, AR
pros: The campus is beautiful! If you are looking to further your education and/or your children then the U of A is for you!  Vacation time and health benefits were fantastic.

review_title: The Center for Learning and Student Access

pros: Fayetteville is a good place to live with low living cost and safe environment. The University is also beautiful. Most staff are very nice.
cons: Whether your working life is enjoyable or miserable is dependent on your boss. There was no supervisor department to supervise how advisors use their people. If you have a bad boss, your life would be horrible.

review_title: It all depends on the department you work in. I worked in Plant genetics and it was great. wonderful co-workers.

cons: Not sure this is a "con", but you have to be very self motivated. you are given a lot of tasks to get done in your own time and if you dont take them seriously and just blow your work off its very obvious.

pros: Love the university's climate, woo pig sooie! Also, the assistantships/fellowships available for graduate students are great, especially considering the low cost of living in Fayetteville.
cons: Some buildings could use some updating, but that's typical of public institutions. Also, pay for summer teaching for graduate students is really, really low. I know we do it for the experience, but come on -- it works out to less than minimum wage!

review_title: Design and help students in solving lab exercises and also reinforce class materials during lab sessions.
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Fayetteville, AR

review_title: Great Opportunities in a Beautiful Location

cons: Salaries are not competitive but the University does offer great health and retirement benefits.  Unfortunately, the cost to park on campus can cost upwards of $700 a year.  Not a small amount based on the average UofA salaries.

pros: It is great to work with students.  The work atmosphere is excellent and you will meet great people.  You will always feel rewarded by making a difference in student's lives.

cons: The weather in Fayettville is good.  Winter is not very cold, but summer is hot.  The university is on the top of a hill, so it is difficult for biking.

review_title: Diverse and Friendly Place to Work
job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Fayetteville, AR
pros: It is a diverse and friendly place to work. I really enjoy helping students access the resources they need to complete their degrees and pursue their higher goals. The benefits are good too.
cons: State institutions that don't offer competitive raises in classified positions, meaning it's very hard to live off of the salary appointed to my position.

pros: Flexible hours, laid back, friend environment, team oriented environment with lots of opportunities. Also lots of training opportunities available.
cons: Scheduling can be difficult at times. There will be days when there are no visitors to the lab which be good or bad.

pros: The job is flexible and has good retirement benefits. The matching plan is very generous: up to 10% of your salary. Vacation time is 15 hour per month and 8 hours per month of sick days.
cons: Medical insurance is getting more and more expensive. Like in many other universities, politics is intense. Some divisions of the University are managed by "good old boys" with a limited vision.

job_title: Administrative Assistant III in Fayetteville, AR
pros: Time off at Christmas. Vacation and sick pay accrue beginning from the first day of employment.
cons: The pay is insulting. Numerous staff have Masters and/or PhD's, and don't even break $30K a year. You have to pay to park, and you better bring your lunch; food on campus is outrageously expensive, and if you leave your parking spot, good luck finding one when you return. Administration seems to do nothing but have meetings upon meetings, and then have all the support staff do the actual work. The university does not give raises, and nearly all positions are dead-end. If you want to advance, you better hope you have a job that allows you to network so you can apply for a better paying job on campus. Everything is about who you know. Unless you don't need to make a living wage, do not, under any circumstances, even consider working at the University of Arkansas. You may have great co-workers on your immediate team (if you're lucky), but the chancellor and all the other overpaid administrative staff aren't losing a minute of sleep over the fact that you can hardly keep a roof over your head. Take your education and skills where they will be valued and compensated fairly.

job_title: Director of Information in Fayetteville, AR
pros: Solid benefits and in an area with a low cost of living, which help offset the low pay.
cons: If you arn't using the benefits such as discount tuition to augment it, the pay is not impressive.

pros: Staff are very flexible about scheduling your hours. Everyone is very friendly and they want to see you succeed.

review_title: Research your research group before joining!
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Fayetteville, AR
pros:
Theoretically good experience if your team is good

Getting an advanced degree is good for your career, depending on what you wish to do.
cons:
-Very poor pay. They encourage us to work between 40 and 60 hour work weeks and give a monthly stipend that averages out to give us less than minimum wage. They justify this by paying for a portion of our tuition, yet still charge us 500 dollars a semester, though that can be as high as 1,000 a semester if you're a foreign student or use the healthcare they make optional.

-Bad management. Every team is different, and some teams have very good management. Mine, in an un-named engineering department, is awful. A few people do the majority of the work while the rest does nothing, as there is no project manager to delegate tasks. The fact that some people can be overloaded while others ask desperately for something to do is embarrassing. Your boss is likely going to be a professor, which means its a shot in the dark whether they're good or not. They could be terrible, boisterous, and rude like mine was, or they could be a genuinely good person who wants the best for you. If applying here, I recommend being very careful that you know which type yours is, because working for someone who values nothing more than their own self can be extremely stressful.

-Poor work/life balance. As mentioned earlier, work life balance is terrible. Some students work seven days a week, while others barely show up for five. Once again the fault of poor management.

-Stressful. Combining the not small course load on top of 40 to 60 hours of work can be extremely stressful.

pros: Good food at the cafeteria, great gym and outdoors programs, great places to go hiking, rock climbing, camping and canoeing around the area and around the State. Fairly good honors college.
